Expectation1: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation1: An armed robbery is in progress, posing immediate threat to lives and property
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story:
I sat in the convent’s small library, sunlight filtering through stained glass, my Bible open on my lap. The peace was almost tangible, and I felt my heart settle as I prepared for an afternoon of quiet reflection. My mind was just beginning to drift into prayer when my police radio, tucked discreetly in my bag, crackled to life. “All units, armed robbery in progress at Main and 5th. Immediate response needed.” My breath caught. I was off duty, but I was still a police officer. I could already picture the chaos—innocent people in danger, the law being broken, and my training urging me to act.

But here, in the silence of the convent, I was Sister Maria, expected to devote myself to spiritual study, to model peace and trust in God’s providence. The sisters relied on me to be present, calm, and focused on our shared faith. Yet the badge in my wallet felt heavy, a reminder of my oath to protect and serve. My hands trembled as I weighed the demands of both worlds, torn between the call to action and the call to contemplation, knowing that whatever I chose, a part of me would be left behind.
